_exec_summary.SummaryText:
40 CFR Part 68.155



Lake Draper Water Treatment Plant (WTP) has adopted this Risk Management Program in order to implement 40

Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 68, the federal requirements regulating risk management of Extremely

Hazardous Substances (EHS). This Program will help prevent the occurrence of, or minimize the consequences of,

catastrophic releases by stating our policies and procedures for the management of process hazards in start-up,

operation, inspection, maintenance, and the other matters addressed in the federal standard.



This Executive Summary includes information required under 40 CFR 68.155.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The Oklahoma City Utilities Department implements a scheduled preventive maintenance program, including

inspection and testing, to minimize the potential for accidental releases. Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs)

have been reviewed and revised to enable the employees to perform their work safely and efficiently and provide

immediate corrective response to any accidents.



The Lake Draper WTP staff are trained to respond in the event of a chemical release incident. Emergency response

to accidental releases is also coordinated with the Oklahoma City Police and Fire Departments and the State and

Local Emergency Response Centers.



Stationary Sources and Regulated Substances

The Lake Draper WTP utilizes chlorine and anhydrous ammonia (regulated substances) as disinfectants in the

drinking water treatment process.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

A Hazard Assessment (Process Hazard Analysis) and written process safety information have been developed to

enable personnel to identify and understand the hazards posed by processes involving EHSs. Process safety

information includes chlorine and anhydrous ammonia information, technology of the process information, and

equipment information.



The Oklahoma City Utilities Engin

eering Division verifies that City-owned WTPs comply with applicable codes and

standards and with recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices (through review of engineering

standards for construction projects).



The Hazard Assessment completed for this Risk Management Plan/Process Safety Management Plan (RMP/PSMP)

documents the process and findings to minimize or eliminate hazards, to mitigate the consequences of hazards of

any releases or other unplanned events, and to reduce the likelihood of exposure to chlorine or anhydrous

ammonia.



Written procedures and information have been developed, implemented, and maintained for each hazardous

process, including steps for each operating phase, operating limits, safety and health considerations, and safety

systems and their functions. All employees involved in working with and around the chlorine and anhydrous

ammonia systems are trained in process and safety procedures, including emergency response on an annual basis.



The mechanical integrity of chlorine and anhydrous ammonia process equipment is documented and maintained

through maintenance, inspection, and testing programs. In addition, a Management of Change program has been

established to ensure proper review of a proposed change to the chlorine or anhydrous ammonia systems.



A pre-startup safety review is performed on new or modified processes to ensure that equipment and

construction meet design specifications, procedures and training have been implemented, and hazard analysis

recommendations have been resolved.



A Compliance Audit Program has also been implemented. The objective of this self-evaluation program is to

ensure that a strong RMP program is maintained, implemented, and followed by appropriate personnel.



Staff have developed a formal documented system to manage incident investigations and follow up. Each incident

that results in, or could reasonably result in, a catastrophic release of chlorine or anhydrous am

monia in the

workplace is investigated and an incident investigation report filed and included in the RMP/PSMP.



Lake Draper WTP Management staff are committed to involving employees, or their representatives, in

supporting the elements of the RMP/PSMP. The following elements involve employee participation regarding the

RMP/PSMP:

? Hazard Assessment, Compliance Audits, and RMP/PSMP reviews and updates

? Employee access to the RMP/PSMP

? An overview training of RMP/PSMP requirements to staff annually

? Development and updating of training for required RMP/PSMP elements

? Any incident investigations and lessons learned for "near miss" event documentation



An authorization and permit program for hot work operations near or around the regulated chlorine and

anhydrous ammonia processes has been implemented at the WTP.



Contractors performing maintenance or repair on or adjacent to chlorine or anhydrous ammonia processes are

instructed in the hazards of the materials onsite prior to commencement of any work and documentation is

maintained regarding contractor understanding of training. In addition, emphasis is placed on knowing how to

respond in the event of emergency.



The WTP chlorine and anhydrous ammonia system technologies are not confidential and any information

regarding the process or process chemistry is available for review in the RMP/PSMP.



Five-Year Accident History

There have been no accidental releases within the past 5 years from the covered processes that resulted in

deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, property damage, or environmental damage.



Emergency Response Program

The RMP/PSMP Emergency Response Plan for the WTP includes the following elements:

? Procedures for informing the public and local emergency response agencies about accidental releases

? Documentation of proper first aid and emergency medical treatment necessary to treat accidental human

exposures

? Procedures and measures for emergency respon

se after an accidental release of a regulated substance

? Procedures for the use of emergency response equipment and for its inspection, testing, and maintenance

? Training for all employees in relevant procedures

? Procedures to review and update, as appropriate, the emergency response plan to reflect changes at

stationary sources to ensure employees are informed of any changes

WTP personnel are trained to take action to control a minor release. Trained personnel will attempt to control a

release within their capability. However, in the event that the release is beyond the control of the operators, they

would immediately notify the Fire Department.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The WTP planned changes to improve safety include increased training and discussion of RMP/PSMP topics in

monthly safety briefings at the WTP and quarterly Department Safety Meetings.
